channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Shooting Aftermath Leaves Homeland Security Department in Turmoil
item.description: As officials point fingers in the wake of Alex Pretti’s death at the hands of federal agents, concerns grow about the agency’s future.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clearing protesters from a hotel in Minneapolis on Sunday night.

item.title: Trump and Schumer Move Toward Possible Deal to Avert a Shutdown
item.description: The president and the top Senate Democrat were discussing an agreement to split off homeland security funding from a broader spending package and negotiate new limits on immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Judge in Minnesota Says ICE Has Violated Nearly 100 Court Orders
item.description: A federal judge said ICE had disobeyed more judicial directives this month than “some federal agencies have violated in their entire existence.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Federal agents arrested and carried a protester in south Minneapolis earlier this month.

item.title: F.B.I. Agents Search Georgia Election Center
item.description: F.B.I. agents searched a Fulton County, Ga., election center for ballots from 2020, escalating an investigation of a heavily Democratic jurisdiction the president has criticized over his defeat.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Richard Fausset and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Votes are counted in November 2024 at the election hub and operations center in Fulton County in Union City, Ga.

item.title: Another Top Kennedy Center Official Resigns
item.description: Kevin Couch, who was announced as senior vice president of artistic programming less than two weeks ago, is the latest to leave since President Trump took control of the center last year.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of The Kennedy Center this month.

item.title: Homelessness Appears to Decline, Reversing a Yearslong Trend
item.description: The Trump administration has not yet released the count, which could complicate its plans for tough new policies.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: A homeless encampment in Chicago in March 2024. Local data collected by The New York Times showed that homelessness fell 60 percent in Chicago in the last year of the Biden administration.

item.title: Why the NORAD Cold War Pact Between the U.S. and Canada Is News
item.description: The State Department clarified comments made by the U.S. Ambassador to Canada that NORAD would be “altered” if that country did not purchase American F-35 jets.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:description: Canada began a review of its agreement to buy F-35 fighter jets from the United States last year. The United States still wants Canada to use those jets for the common defense of North American airspace.

item.title: At World’s Busiest Port, China’s Unbalanced Economy Comes Into View
item.description: The shipping traffic and factories never stop in China’s port city of Ningbo, but the local housing market has crashed and nearby restaurants sit empty.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

item.title: U.K.’s Starmer Meets Xi Jinping in Beijing as Ties Warm
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain met with President Xi Jinping of China as he sought to promote business ties with the world’s second-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Chinese and British delegations participating in a bilateral meeting with President Xi Jinping and Prime Minister Keir Starmer in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Will Submit Monthly Budget to White House
item.description: Democrats sharply questioned the plan, including the role of Qatar in managing an account funded by the sale of Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations during a hearing to examine U.S. policy towards Venezuela.

item.title: Who Will Win the Best Actor Oscar?
item.description: In an exceptionally strong field, Timothée Chalamet, Leonardo DiCaprio, Ethan Hawke, Michael B. Jordan and Wagner Moura each have a way to triumph.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Trump Threatens Iran With ‘Massive Armada’ and Presses a Set of Demands
item.description: U.S. and European officials say they have put three demands in front of the Iranians, including a permanent end to all enrichment of uranium.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The USS Abraham Lincoln in 2024. The aircraft carrier group is currently stationed in striking distance of targets in Iran.

item.title: Man Sentenced to 15 Years for Role in Plot to Kill Iranian Dissident
item.description: Carlisle Rivera became the third person to be sentenced for playing a role in trying to kill Masih Alinejad, an activist and a critic of the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masih Alinejad leaves Federal District Court in Manhattan after testifying in the trial of two men charged with plotting to assassinate her.

item.title: How His Duel With Trump Boosted Emmanuel Macron, France’s Embattled President
item.description: Dismissed as a lame duck, Emmanuel Macron has clawed back some influence after his defense of Greenland and Denmark. Will quieter domestic politics allow him to secure his legacy?
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: French President Emmanuel Macron meeting on Wednesday with Denmark’s Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen, right, and Greenland Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen.

item.title: She Couldn’t Defend Herself, but He Wasn’t Charged With Rape
item.description: A decision in China not to charge a man who fathered children with a woman with a mental illness has set off a debate about consent and the state’s push for babies.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Amazon’s $35 Million ‘Melania’ Promotion Has Critics Questioning Its Motives
item.description: The tech giant is spending $35 million to promote its film about the first lady, far more than is typical for documentaries.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: Amazon paid Melania Trump’s production company $40 million for the rights to the documentary. That amount is about $26 million more than the offer from the next closest bidder, Disney.

item.title: South Africa Cancels Release of ‘Melania’ Documentary
item.description: The distributor, which was set to release the film on Friday, said it had canceled the theatrical premiere because of “recent developments,” but declined to specify.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, at the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, where she rang the opening bell.

item.title: Tens of Thousands in Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana Without Power After Storm
item.description: Across Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana, hundreds of power lines and poles remained damaged after freezing rain and low temperatures coated much of the region in ice over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Linemen work to restore power in Oxford, Miss., on Monday.

item.title: After Winter Storm, New York Uses Hot Tubs to Melt the Snow
item.description: With no warm weather expected any time soon, the city’s snow piles require mechanical intervention.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Maag
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York’s snow melters, like this one here in Lower Manhattan, are not particularly hot. The water inside them is heated to only 38 degrees.

item.title: Who’s Supposed to Clear the Snow From New York City’s Street Corners?
item.description: Three days after the city’s biggest snowstorm in years, many New Yorkers are still scaling mounds of snow and ice. Cleaning it up is a shared responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times
item.media:description: While New York City’s streets have been cleared since a major snowstorm on Sunday, cold temperatures have kept the remaining snow from melting, leaving it piled on sidewalks.

item.title: Another Weekend Winter Storm? Forecast Details and Updates.
item.description: Here’s what meteorologists know about the next storm that is expected to hit the East Coast.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: The forecast could change before the weekend, but it’s looking more likely that another winter storm will affect part of the East Coast.

item.title: Sergey Brin Spends $20 Million on California Political Effort Amid Wealth Tax Debate
item.description: Sergey Brin donated $20 million to a new political drive aimed at solving California’s housing crisis, spurring other billionaires to pitch in. Their efforts may also help ward off a wealth tax.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall and Theodore Schleifer
item.media:description: Sergey Brin’s group says it is trying to solve problems and help middle-class workers pay for housing in a state where the median home price has surpassed $850,000.

item.title: 5 Key Takeaways from Josh Shapiro’s Memoir ‘Where We Keep the Light’
item.description: Politically pointed and heavy on his Jewish faith, the book already has Democrats talking.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania

item.title: Judge Questions Trump Administration’s Push to Halt Congestion Pricing
item.description: As a legal battle continues over the fate of New York City’s toll program, a judge appeared skeptical of the federal government’s arguments, but did not issue a ruling.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Winnie Hu
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congestion pricing went into effect last January for drivers entering Manhattan below 60th Street.

item.title: Camping on Thwaites Glacier
item.description: After working and camping for a week on Thwaites Glacier, scientists were ready to start drilling into the ice, if only the weather would let them.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Greenland Envoy: We Need ‘Total, Unfettered Access’
item.description: Trump’s special envoy to Greenland argues that the U.S. needs Greenland to defend it, American allies and American security.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Landry
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: No Child Deserves to Die Like My Daughter
item.description: What was done to my daughter did not break me. It left me with a mother’s responsibility to ensure no child is left unheard.
item.dc:creator: Wesam Hamada
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Shannon Lin/The New York Times. Photograph courtesy Wesam Hamada.

item.title: Driver Rams Car Into Headquarters of Chabad Hasidic Movemen
item.description: No one was injured when the motorist drove into a rear door of the building on Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. The man was arrested; the police are investigating the incident as a hate crime.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Brian Josephs
item.media:description: After a motorist rammed his car into a side entrance of the global headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitch Orthodox Jewish movement in Brooklyn, police officers swarmed the scene.

item.title: Tesla Profit Slumps, but Investors May Not Care
item.description: The automaker also said it would invest $2 billion in xAI, the artificial intelligence company controlled by its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and stop making the two oldest models in its lineup.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Falling car sales have taken a toll on Tesla’s net profit. The company announced Wednesday that it would stop producing its S and X model cars within months.

item.title: Mamdani Blames Rivals for Leaving New York With a ‘Poisoned’ Budget
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said the only way to close a more than $12 billion budget gap was to raise taxes on the wealthy and corporations.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, joined by his budget director, Sherif Soliman, left, and Deputy Mayor Dean Fuleihan, warned of a huge budget gap.

item.title: Victim in School Sex Abuse Case Wins $30 Million Jury Award
item.description: The man, now 44, said that a teacher in Newark repeatedly sexually abused him in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ann Street School in Newark, where a 44-year-old man said he was abused as a child by an after-school teacher in the 1990s.
